raw_text:
Sony PSP handheld console hits US
 
 The latest handheld gaming gadget, Sony's PlayStation Portable, goes on sale in the US on Thursday.
 
 The entertainment device, which also stores images, music and video, is intended to compete with Nintendo's DS, released earlier this month in the UK. Gamers have been queuing outside shops across the US to get their hands on the gadget, which costs $250 (about £132). The first million sold will come with the Spider-Man 2 film on UMD, Sony's own disc format for the device. The PSP can be linked up with others for multiplayer gaming, via a wireless connection. Sony has touted the machine as the Walkman of the 21st Century and has sold more than 800,000 units in Japan since its launch there last year.
 
 But it faces stiff competition from the Nintendo DS, which sold more than the GameCube in its first few days on release in Europe. It too allows for multiplayer gaming over the air. Nintendo dominates the handheld market, with more than a 90% share of the market in the US alone. The Gizmondo combined media player, phone and gaming gadget also went on sale in the UK last week. It hopes to take a share of the handheld gaming market too.
 
 "The story of the PSP is it's not a gaming device as much as it is a portable entertainment device," said Michael Pachter, analyst at Wedbush Morgan Securities. He told the Reuters news agency that he expected Sony to sell about 10 million PSPs in enough time to rival Apple's iPod. There is no date for the PSP's release in Europe yet. Sony has promised to have a million units ready for its US launch, but there are fears demand may not be met. It also said it expected to ship three million PSPs worldwide by the end of its fiscal year ending 31 March.
 
 The machine's European launch was put back "a few months" last week in order to make sure enough of the devices were ready for its US launch, as well as satisfying the Japanese market. The PSP has almost as much processing power in it as the PlayStation 2 console. Hundreds of gamers gathered at US shops, some waiting for more than 36 hours, to be the first to get their hands on the gadget. A spokesman for one US shop said it expected the device to sell out on its first day. The 24 games for the mini console include Ape Academy, Formula One, Wipeout Pure and Fired Up. Movie studios, including Lions Gate Entertainment and Disney, have also announced forthcoming film titles that will be made available on the UMD format.
llama3.2:1b: Sony's PlayStation Portable (PSP) is a handheld gaming device that was released in the US on Thursday.
It costs $250 and includes a Spider-Man 2 film on UMD.
The PSP can connect to others for multiplayer gaming via wireless connection, and it has sold over 800,000 units in Japan since its launch last year.
Sony expects to sell around 10 million PSPs globally by the end of 2013.

The device allows for multiplayer gaming and comes with a few pre-loaded games.
Sony expects to sell 10 million units worldwide by end of fiscal year, rivaling Apple's iPod sales.

Movie studios are also planning releases on the device's UMD platform.

smollm:1.7b: The Sony PSP handheld console hits US market in the US on Thursday, with a price tag of $250 (about £132).
The device is designed to compete with Nintendo's DS and offers multiplayer gaming capabilities via wireless connection.
Sony has touted the machine as the "Walkman of the 21st Century" and has sold more than 800,000 units in Japan since its launch there last year.
However, it faces stiff competition from Nintendo's DS, which sold more than the GameCube in its first few days on release in Europe.
The PSP is designed to be a portable entertainment device that can also store images, music and video.
It has a 24-hour battery life and supports Wi-Fi connectivity for online gaming.
The story of the PSP is it's not a gaming device as much as it is a portable entertainment device.
The PSP is designed to be more than just a handheld console that allows gamers to play games on the go, but rather a device that can store media and provide access to music and video content.
Sony has promised to sell about 10 million units in enough time to rival Apple's iPod, which has sold over 250 million units worldwide since its launch in 2006.
There is no date for the PSP's release in Europe yet, but Sony has said it expects to ship three million units worldwide by the end of its fiscal year ending 31 March.

The device supports several movies, including Ape Academy, Formula One, Wipeout Pure, and Fired Up.

Sony expects to sell over 10 million PSPs in time for its European launch, and hopes to compete with Apple's iPod for a share of the global portable entertainment market.
In Japan, Sony has already sold more than 800,000 units in one month since their launch, and will likely continue to dominate the handheld console market as they have done in the past.
The PlayStation Portable's European launch was delayed by almost two months due to ensuring enough devices were ready for its US launch.

granite3.1-dense:2b: Sony's PlayStation Portable (PSP), a versatile handheld gaming console, debuts in the US on Thursday at $250 per unit.
The PSP, marketed as a "Walkman of the 21st Century," competes with Nintendo's DS, which has already made significant strides in Europe.

While Sony aims to sell about 10 million units globally, including one million during its US launch, it faces strong competition from Nintendo, which dominates the handheld market with over a 90% share in the US.
The PSP supports various media formats, such as games, images, music, and video, and can be linked for multiplayer gaming.
With nearly PlayStation 2's processing power, it features 24 launch titles, including Ape Academy, Formula One, Wipeout Pure, and Fired Up.
Movie studios like Lions Gate Entertainment and Disney have also pledged forthcoming film releases on the UMD format.
Despite pre-orders and eager crowds at US stores, there are concerns about meeting demand due to delayed European shipments.
